data.message: Just because one doesn't agree with gay marriage doesn't mean they hate...quit labeling

replies.message: Replace "gay marriage" in that sentence with another minority group and see how it sounds to you.
"Just because one doesn't agree with [atheists] doesn't mean they hate...quit labeling"  nah, still sounds rational to me
people just don't agree on certain things ..doesnt mean they hate
Actually, it sounds fine. Just because you don't agree with someone, doesn't mean you automatically hate them. I don't agree with your views, but I don't hate you. Since when is that a crime?

I don't agree. I'm Christian, yet I have some gay/lesbian friends that are great people. I won't vote against them, neither will I vote for them. I don't see it as being my choice what someone else can and can't do. Does that make sense lol?

Disagreeing with something (in most cases) doesn't automatically mean "hate." However, when one starts to take actions to limit others ... such as prohibiting them to have the same rights shared by the majority ... that's when it clearly becomes some type of hate, no matter how sweet you try to coat it.

Sam: Then whose choice is it? If it's each individual's choice, doesn't that mean that you support allowing gay marriage? If it's not any human's choice, then how should that be reflected in law? By abstaining all you're doing is giving the choice to those who do vote.
Bill Rhoades if you don't agree with gay marriage, why do you want to marry a gay? it seems illogical
"just because I don't agree with black voting rights doesn't mean I hate those people"  -about the same as the anti gay crowd
i don't like fried chicken and feel it is really bad for me but yet I would never try to stop someone else from being able to legally eat fried chicken
